properties.data-D-SpeChar: Special furniture designed by Piccaluga,covered terrace on the ground floor,cross ventilation on all floors,three-dimensional grid of concrete posts and slabs left apparent,the filling with concrete block walls offeres a coherrent inside-outside interplay,vertical opening facing the siting area and the circulation,camp-like structure,built in seating,bedrooms have openings that open to each other
properties.data-O-OtFcInv: Grid of concrete posts and slabs left apparent
properties.data-P-SpcScMn: Weekend house to bsat,alot of people used to visit the bsat family because they used to export of foodstuffs to outside of lebanon
properties.data-Q-Bibliography:
The Bsat house sits in orange orchards near the city of Tyre in South Lebanon. It is partly elevated on pilotis giving way to a covered terrace on the ground floor, very useful in this particular setting where the owners often invited people to outdoor parties. 
The general layout allows for cross ventilation on all floors.
The house is built with a three-dimensional grid of concrete posts and slabs left apparent. The filling with concrete block walls, plastered and painted white, offers a coherent inside-outside interplay. The rule is simplD: the east and west grids are either fully blocked with a wall, or have two side walls leaving an opening in the middle that faces the sitting area or have a wall on one side, giving a vertical opening that faces the circulation towards the bedrooms.
The southern side offers generous openings that overlook the fields, only interrupted by the concrete posts. In this straightforward layout, the successive floors seem to overlap to get a glimpse of the view. The camp-like structure and design does not fail on the detailing level, with built-in seating and sensitive use of materials both in and out. The Piccaluga brothers demonstrate here their mastery of detailing and use of materials and textures.

House and garden dec 1966 pp. 178-183,Arbitare n 69 oct 1968
properties.data-R-Notes: The house was sold a year ago to Mr ismail farran

properties.data-D-SpeChar: Singular Structure, looks like a flying saucer that has landed on the beach, Cylindrical Building, sits on wide pilotis,
properties.data-Q-Bibliography:
This very singular structure resembling a flying saucer was built on the Mediterranean sea shore at a location named Acapulco Beach in Ouzai. Four elliptical columns widen as they rise to carry the cylindrical building.�A minimalist spiral staircase at its core surrounded by a thin steel fence keeps the open view to the sea at the entrance level and leads to a ring-like landing that gives to the various rooms around.
The furniture and lighting fixtures were designed by Jean Roy�re, a French designer who had opened a successful business in Beirut, producing furniture locally with a Lebanese partner, architect Nadim Majdalani.
Currently the chalet is invaded by squatters.

- Arab Center for Architecture - Maurice Hindie collection 

- Practicing Modernism in Beirut - Architecture in Lebanon, 1946 - 1970 (p.209)

properties.data-D-SpeChar: Shape follows the curved street,high ceiling,space above the entrance serves as a terrace,leveling of the terraces
properties.data-J-OtFlFns: Colored concrete tiles and colored terrazzo on the stairs
properties.data-P-SpecHsEv: German army stayed in the building during World War 2
properties.data-P-SpcScMn: His mother was an author so she held cultural events on the terraces
properties.data-Q-Bibliography:
This is a modernist apartment building by Bahjat Abdulnour who oscillated between unabashed eclecticism and modern style. In this apartment building, the shape follows closely the curved street. 
The unadorned walls are finished with Tyrolean plaster, a rough finishing that was widespread in the 1940s. 
Due to the slope, the building is organized in split-levels and each landing serves one apartment. Given the high ceilings, the space above the entrance serves as a terrace alternatively to one apartment and the other, optimizing the use. The last floor was added by architect Ferdinand Dagher in 1959.
The building was recently well renovated, keeping with its original features, a rare and commendable endeavor in the general attitude of demolition or disrespectful renovation.

"Practicing Modernism in Beirut, Architecture in Lebanon,1946-1970" by Dr George J. Arbid

properties.data-D-SpeChar: Core housing an elevator with circular landing,open air courts on the side,checkered plan,gentle curve on the facade.
properties.data-Q-Bibliography:
The unconventional plan of this apartment building is quite representative of the work of William Saba.*
The building has a core housing an elevator, a spiral staircase and a circular landing serving four apartments per floor. Two open air courts on the sides accommodate the apartments, while the checkered plan in the rear brings light to the stairwell and landings.
The organization around a central cylindrical core gives the main elevation on Rue Pasteur its gentle curve.
The building was erected with limestone from the quarries of Ayn Ebel.

properties.data-O-OtFcInv: Perforated Veil, Eternite Walkway Shading Panels
properties.data-Q-Bibliography:
Makdisi Building was founded in 1954 on the corner of the intersection of Makdisi with Jeanne D�arc Street. It was built by the polish architect Karol Schayer along with his Lebanese associates Bahij Makdisi and Wassik Adib. Thus, the street was named after the building�s founders. It�s an apartment building composed of six floors with three apartments per floor. Generally speaking, one can directly notice that there�s a clear balance between volumes, voids, verticality, horizontal bands blank walls, flying canopies, and free standing circular columns. There�s also this desire to avoid direct intersection of planes but rather let them slide against each other. Of the major features of Makdisi building are the framed protruding grid, erect staircase, and two major canopies marking the penthouse. All five typical floors are treated in the same manner; however, the penthouse is dealt with a different technique. The facades are merely expressions of the interior and the various materials used mark changes in functions or spaces. The whole composition of the building is well studied so that when moving from one volume to another, one barely notices the huge mass of the whole but rather starts to focus on how theses planes and volumes merge together within the elegant body of Makdisi building. 

- Arab Center for Architecture - Schayer & Adib & Makdisi collection 

- Practicing Modernism in Beirut - Architecture in Lebanon, 1946 - 1970 (p.117)
properties.data-R-Notes: Original drawings done by AUB students

properties.data-D-SpeChar: T-shaped building in a triangular site, Exposed blocks made of cast stone designed as a sophisticated kit-system
properties.data-Q-Bibliography:
This is one of the finest apartment buildings of the early 1950s in Beirut with its siting, apartments layout, massing, materials, and detail refinement. The architects took full advantage of a difficult triangular site with a T-shaped building under which they created a pedestrian path linking the two adjoining streets in the Sanayeh district.
The inventive exposed blocks made of cast stone, a cement-based material with limestone aggregate as primary constituent, are designed as a sophisticated kit-system in which wall blocks, sills, lintels, jambs, and other architectonic elements are manufactured in special shapes.
A hierarchy in the reading of the large structure, thus reducing its impact, is achieved by a skillful composition of volumes and finishes in which the aggregate blocks and surfaces of red bricks are combined with striped and textured plaster.




- Arab Center for Architecture - George Rais Collection

- Practicing Modernism In Beirut - Architecture in Lebanon, 1946 -1970 by George J. Arbid (p. 206)

properties.data-A-BldgName: Jounieh sports stadium or Fouad Chehab Stadium
properties.data-D-SpeChar: One bleacher roof that covers 2 stadiums,roof that collects rainwater,services under gradins.
properties.data-P-SpecHsEv: Alot of important games happened in the stadium
properties.data-P-SpcScMn: Sports facility that teams uses to play
properties.data-Q-Bibliography:
The remarkable structure was studied by engineer No�l Abouhamad. As Khalil Khoury saw the drawings of the bending moment, he suggested to Abouhamad to use the shape literally for the design of the roof. 
The structure was executed in prestressed concrete with one central span of 34 meters and two cantilevers of 17 meters and 5 meters respectively. The gigantic roof sits on two beams that additionally collect rainwater, evacuating it on the sides.
Architect Khalil Khoury combined the basketball court and the gradins cover under one roof . That was an appropriate solution in a narrow site, allowing to hide the services under the gradins. More importantly, it proved to be structurally sound since it reduced the anchoring needed to balance the load of the cantilevers on both sides. 
The corrugated surface of the roof keeps exposed the ridges and grooves resulting from the shape of the bending moment.
Execution was carried out by engineers Alfred Matta and Pedro Khoury.
The stadium is also known as the Fouad Chehab Stadium.

AL mouhandess 1973

properties.data-H-OtStrShp: Linear stair part of the seating
properties.data-P-SpcScMn: Clarisses sisters are a closed society, it is seen in the architecture. The sisters tend to meet behind the church, in a more private area.
properties.data-Q-Bibliography:
After he had designed the Convent of the Clarisses Sisters, architect Pierre El Khoury was overloaded with work. He called in Jacques Liger-Belair to design the convent�s chapel. This initiative gave the latter an opportunity to design and build an important sculptural building of the time. With its exposed concrete, the free form of the chapel sits as an event before the ordered composition of the main building surrounding the cloister. It allows for both the sisters and the public to celebrate Mass without being in full presence of each other.
In fine weather, three wide doors, located on the side of the chapel, can be fully opened and allow for more worshipers to participate in the celebration.
�
No doubt, the chapel owes its source of inspiration to Notre Dame du Haut in Ronchamp, by Le Corbusier, while the austerity and roughness of exposed concrete are more akin to the Convent of La Tourette, by the same architect.
�
The very difficult concrete ceiling formwork was executed by contractor Elie Saghbini.

-Arab Center for Architecure - Jacques Liger-Belair collection 

- Practicing Modernism in Beirut - Architecture in Lebanon, 1946 - 1970 (p.242)

properties.data-D-SpeChar: Prefabricated raw concrete in an hexagonal shape, it can be built individually or in several examples grouped in cells.
properties.data-P-SpcScMn:
Maurice Hindie the architect designed the chalet for himself. It is therefore a testimony to his beliefs in several aspects of his profession: 
Space production, construction, and  economy
properties.data-Q-Bibliography:
In 1972, he built for himself a prefabricated Chalet made of two identical pieces precast in concrete, located in the ski resort of Faraya. In this prototype, the two-storey interior is optimized with a witty section using the sloping sides as steps and couches. The architect originally planned to build six interlocking cascading units, but only one unit was built.

Programm: The programm concerns
a group of six chalets for a ski Station.
Guiding concepts: The good weather
lasting only three to four months, the type of construction chosen consists in precasting in factory and assembling on site.
For economic reasons a unique form has been adopted for the ceiling and the floor.
This shape allows to stick the chalets together (overlapping of one third), liberating thus the maximum of the land and giving to the whole a form bound to the slope.
Inside this shell and in its middle,
a slab is suspended giving way from
the ground floor to the first through
a double height on both sides.
The ground floor is made of steps covered with moquette and pillows thus replacing the traditional furniture.
At the first are located three bedrooms wide opened on the living. The Kitchen is bound to the dining angle and gives way to the living room.
Aesthetics : In order to stress on the idea of a shelter the moquette covering the floor is raised on the steps and the walls.
In that atmosphere of uniform colour stare out pillows, the doors and the radiators treated with vivid colors.

-Arab Center for Architecture - Maurice Hindie collection 

- Practicing Modernism in Beirut - Architecture in Lebanon, 1946 - 1970 (p.63)

properties.data-Q-Bibliography:
he idea behind Phoenicia Hotel emerged in late 1953, when a group of investors, encouraged by the Lebanese authorities, founded La Soci�t� des Grands H�tels du Liban, and started planning for the design of a prestigious hotel in Beirut. Edward Durell Stone, an American architect, was called in for the design, and he was associated with local engineers/architects F. Dagher and R. Elias. The appointed hotel manager, Max Hamburger, was also part of the consulting team. Construction began in March 1954. The hotel was inaugurated on the 23rd of December 1961. The Phoenicia Hotel was soon to become an icon of modern design in the International Style, adapted to the local Mediterranean climate, and coping with local conditions. In its first version, the hotel was named Savoy-Plaza Hotel. In 1956, during construction, the Intercontinental Hotel Corporation was associated on the project and two floors were added, increasing the number of rooms from 210 to 325.
Electrical and Mechanical engineer was Peter Bruder, structural engineering by Gorling and Atlas, structural solution for adding the floors by Professor Eraste Langhade (ESIB professor). Original interior design schemes by 5 teams of American decorators and a Swiss, Huffschmitt, supplemented in the expanded version by the Ballard Corporation of New York.]

Monde Liban mai-juin 1969 / p. LXXXXII,PART ONE, Chapter 5, "Reconstruction: Modernism Affected."
AL majalis in Arabic 1954,"Practicing Modernism in Beirut, Architecture in Lebanon,1946-1970" by Dr George J. Arbid

properties.data-P-SpcScMn: Ground floor piazza open to the public with two major attractions in the city, cinema "Etoile" and restaurant cafe "Express". Caf� Express became very famous during the Civil War, after Red Horse Caf�, just two blocks down the�street, closed. The caf� hosted important political meetings and was frequented by journalists,�intellectuals, activists and politicians. Its location across the street from Dar An Nahar publishing house�also attracted artists, poets and writers.
properties.data-Q-Bibliography:
Mme Lucienne Sabbag was after "a building with character" and wanted a world-class architect for her bank and office building in the developing district of Hamra, Ras Beirut. She eventually commissioned Finnish architect Alvar Aalto (1898-1976)�whom she�preferred for "the simple and classical side in his work." As Aalto thought that Beirut was too far from Finland for "the old man he was", he suggested to design the building in partnership with Swiss architect Alfred Roth (1903-1998),�with whom he had collaborated.
The building is more Roth�s design than Aalto�s, except for the rear elevation, broken and treated with sharp-edged horizontal profiles acting as sun-breakers, and the enameled tiles covering the bank headquarters, produced by Aalto in Finland. The rest is very "Swiss", straightforward, precise, and well detailed. The superior quality materials were carefully chosen and approved by Mme Sabbag personally. The L-shaped building frees the corner giving way to the perpendicular streets and offers a piazza to the pedestrian neighborhood.
Like many important operations, the project was carried out with a group of Lebanese consultants, technicians and superintendents.�Hanna Heneineh represented the client (assisted by Michel Mourad, engineer), Hagop Atechian was architect on site, architect Pierre El Khoury was consultant.
Structural and Sanitary studies by engineer No�l Abouhamad, Electrical studies by�Naggear and Yared, Air Conditioning studies by�Jamil Abdulnour.
The building is currently owned by Fransabank. The ground floor function used to be open for the public now it is closed. 


- Arab Center for Architecture - Alvar Alto & Alfred Roth Collection 

- Practicing Modernism In Beirut - Architecture in Lebanon, 1946 - 1970 by Dr. George J. Arbid (p. 44)

properties.data-Q-Bibliography:
The City Center, a souk, movie theater, and office building is symptomatic of a situation in which the building code unwittingly becomes a catalyst of distinguished architectural design. In the 1960s, the building code was strict about movie theaters, and law then forbade building above them for structural safety. As a result, they were naturally confined in basements, with open-air courts above.  In a move to avoid any loss of space, Karam managed to convince the authorities that the law did not forbid the use of the space below the movie theaters, and he created a retail space underneath. Once the movie theater was raised and visible, he was forced to give it a distinguished shape, hence the concrete eggshell that became an unusual but important landmark on the Beirut skyline.
The difficult formwork was drawn by Georges Kamel Abboud at J.P. Karam's office.
Structural design by No�l Abouhamad.
The 1000 seat egg-shaped cinema hall is 24 meters wide and 11 meters high.

"Practicing Modernism in Beirut, Architecture in Lebanon,1946-1970" by Dr George J. Arbid,Monde Liban mai-juin 1969/p.194,Promotional Brochure
properties.data-R-Notes: The buildings follows the international style if the 50s & 60s marked by a heavy rational based of beam column construction, surrounding an elliptical flat dome used as cinema. The based supports an office tower fitted with steel and glass curtain wall as the front fa�ade. The back fa�ade is characterized by horizontal bands of rendered concrete separating the window meeting a marble clad sheer wall on the side elevation. The roof is set back with a punched cantilever for sun protection

properties.data-D-SpeChar: Curved facade,Pergula on top,American life panel on below,Atrium,louvers
properties.data-Q-Bibliography:
The Pan American Building designed by George Rais and Th�o Canaan, assisted by Assem Salam, is a finely proportioned and well detailed building that drew its richness from appropriate understanding of, and response to, rational needs. Here, the implementation in Riad Solh Square at the prow of the street and the need to react differently in terms of sun control on the east and south elevations, determined design choices. Rais created a subtle balance between a separate reading of the sides and the unity of the building as a whole. An attention to human scale is found in various aspects of the building, namely in the eastern wall which shifts back at pedestrian level, to define the entrance on Rue Riad Solh. 
The building had a mobile by Alexander Calder who came to Beirut at the time (he was a friend of Henri Seyrig).

Architectural design,vol. 27, march 1957,p. 105,"Practicing Modernism in Beirut, Architecture in Lebanon,1946-1970" by Dr George J. Arbid

properties.data-D-SpeChar: First curtain wall in the country
properties.data-P-SpcScMn: Arab intellectuals used to gather at the horseshoe
properties.data-Q-Bibliography:
Between 1949, when the office building for the Kadisha electric company was built in Tripoli, and 1957, year of construction of the Murr office building in Hamra Street in Beirut, a major evolution had happened in the building technology: the development of the curtain wall.�
Steiger and Kaldany 1963�
The�Murr�Building is mostly known as the �Horse-Shoe Building� in reference to the coffee-restaurant that occupied the ground floor for many years.
Built in 1957, it is the first curtain-wall in the country, a few years only after the Lever House (1952) designed in New York City by Gordon Bunshaft for Skidmore Owings and Merrill.
The glass fa�ade was executed with extruded aluminum members. Bands of clear glass alternate with bands of colored glass at slab level. The drawings reveal the �bricolage� that was necessary to produce such a feat in a country with low-tech building industry. The firm designed also an extension of the building in the rear that was never implemented.
The side wall on the Eastern side was clad with 2x2cm ceramic tiles of pink-beige color that matched the travertine marble. It was later plastered.
The building shares a wall on its Western side with the Al-Hamra Cinema and Office Building, its predecessor of a few months inaugurated in October 1957. Together, they set a direction for many buildings that followed, that of a straightforward glass fa�ade facing North, whether curtain-wall or not. This appropriate solution for light provision in Beirut�s hot climate was followed by several buildings on the street that will benefit from the northern light.
Although one could imagine the competition between the architects, both Rais and Schayer held each other in high esteem. In a rare move aiming at achieving a degree of continuity with the neighboring building, the design that Schayer produced with Makdisi and Associates was synchronized with the height of the slabs of the Al-Hamra building. More coordination was sought by the architects as they intended to open the wall that separated the two buildings at the sidewalk level in order to offer a wider perspective for pedestrians.
The plan layout is straightforward, circulation being at the back and serving uninterruptedly the 38m x 9m open slabs that face the street and receive the northern light. Aluminum is also used in the cladding of the circular columns on the ground floor.

- Practicing Modernism in Beirut - Architecture in Lebanon, 1946 - 1970 (p.120)

- Arab Center for Architecture - Karol Schayer and Wassek Adib with B. Makdisi collection

properties.data-D-SpeChar: Creating a a series of shells allowing light to penetrate through the joints creating an interplay of light and shadow within the space
properties.data-G-OtrBUsg: Conference, Lobby, Store, Kitchen, Men's Toilet
properties.data-G-OtFlrsUs: Imam's apartment and office, Community Center, Library, Mezzanine
properties.data-P-SpcScMn: As a religious building the aysha bakkar mosque definitely carries a social meaning as a religious place of workship.
properties.data-Q-Bibliography:
In the Aysha Bakkar Mosque and community center, Tukan rightly acknowledges and uses a crooked site shape in a busy quarter of Beirut. The program required the provision of a prayer hall on the street level to serve the maximum number of believers, a religious library and a small apartment accommodating the Sheik of the mosque. The departure from the traditional mosque vocabulary was an attempt to create a contemporary building which retains the basic characteristics and atmosphere of a place of worship.
The irregular boundaries of the site as well as the noisy location necessitated the generation of a form occupying fully the site closed enough to minimize the noise yet allowing for light to fill the space.
The scheme is conceived as a series of shells, with light penetrating through the joints to create within the space an interplay of light and shadow. The Mihrab is part of the overall composition and is designed as the natural end of the shells that taper into it.
Text by Tukan describing the project:
1)Functional requirements
To provide for a prayer hall on the street level to serve the maximum number of believers, a religious library and a small apartment accommodating the sheik of the mosque.
2) Physical/environmental setting
The site was left over from the opening of two main roads � a highway crossing a street. The boundaries of the site being so irregular as well as the location being so noisy and crowded necessitated the generation of a form projecting the site and closed enough to minimize the noise yet allowing for light to fill the space.
3)Design innovation
The scheme is conceived as a series of shells allowing light to penetrate through the joints creating an interplay of light and shadow within the space.� The shells taper into the (Mihrab) of the mosque which eventually becomes a natural end to these shells.� The form of the mosque was intended to be minimalistic in generating the form of the mosque, since as a general attitude we felt that the masses have enough interest to enable us to avoid the addition of the decorative elements and be contended with a simple calligraphy on the front fa�ade.
To be consistent with this approach and since in our age we use electronic devices for prayer call, we thought the provision of a balcony for the minaret was unnecessary.� Instead speakers were installed.

- Jaafar Tukan: Poetry in Stone by James Steele (p.16-19)

- Practicing Modernism in Beirut - Architecture in Lebanon, 1946 - 1970 (p.250)

properties.data-D-SpeChar: The plan is a juxtaposition of two distinct parts. The first is a cubic enclosed space of prayer, dressed with sandstone, framed by freestanding concrete columns, and capped with a complex concrete shell -a modern interpretation of the dome (The shape of the roof is a local take on Felix Candela�s experiments in concrete shells).
properties.data-P-SpcScMn: The mosque definitely carries a social meaning as a religious place of workship.
properties.data-Q-Bibliography:
In the Khashojki Mosque of 1965, Salam combined once again the materials he had used in earlier projects in a clear straightforward way. The plan is a juxtaposition of two distinct parts. The first is a cubic enclosed space of prayer, dressed with sandstone, framed by freestanding concrete columns, and capped with a complex concrete shell -a modern interpretation of the dome (The shape of the roof is a local take on Felix Candela�s experiments in concrete shells).� The second is an adjacent outdoor space, surrounded by walking galleries and covered by a concrete slab with clerestory openings all around. Next to it stands a square minaret dressed in sandstone, with vertical crannies looking like arrow slits, an idea the architect had developed with the team of the Lebanese Pavilion to the New York Fair. Albeit the Martyr�s Mosque is a meaningful modern contribution to Islamic architecture, its concrete cast pointed-arch galleries surrounding the outdoor space leave a sense of compromise that does a disservice to the otherwise coherent and reserved idiom. The literal 'd�tournement' operated here lies rather in the disposition of those elements that stand perpendicularly to the main elevation, whereas one expects to see them participate in the fa�ade. Instead, they offer to the street their profile, reduced here to a simple rectangular support.

- Arab Center for Architecture - Assem Salam collection

properties.data-P-SpecHsEv:
The St. Georges hotel was named after the legend of Saint Georges, the hero said to have slain a dragon terrorizing the shores of the bay. 
At the time of its conception, Lebanon was still under the rule of the French Mandate and so visitors of the hotel were almost exclusively French nationals.
In the 1960's, the hotel popularity peaked following Lebanons independence and it gained huge reputation.
In 1975, the Lebanese civil war broke out, putting business to a stop. In the following years, it became too expensive for many. 
In 1983, militias began occupying the five-star resort in the area, transforming them into bases. 
The building has sustained significant damage, and was in deep need of renovations. 
Before any steps could be taken towards the improvement of the hotel, Lebanon's former Prime Minister Rafiq al Hariri set about the reconstructing Beirut's entire central and waterfront districts. 
Under the name of the newly-founded construction company Solidere in 1994, Rafiq al Hariri was granted a myriad of rights for the purpose of rebuilding the city. El Khoury refused, sparkling a long-term fight with Solidere. 
Solidere blocked St. George's acces to the sea. 
In 2005, Harriri was assissinated by a bombing that targeted his convoy as it passed the hotel. 
The building's intial structure withheld the damage, leaving the building with a burnt facade. 
The St. Georges Hotel's pool and restaurant have remained open to the public use, but the hotel was off limits. 
In 2019, Solidere's contract with St. Georges ended. 
In 2020, El Khoury, after being coerced to give up the hotel and his plans for renovation, will finally be able to restore a building that has been haunted by its city's violence and corruption for decades.

Lebanons article put source
properties.data-P-SpcScMn:
St. Georges hotel is one of the Beirut's oldest remaining landmarks, the building's aged exterior has stood the test of time, war, and bombings. 
It has a strategic location at the tip of the bay that made the hotel incredibly popular amongst upper class visitors who frequented the hotel its adjacent beach and boat club. 
Following independence, it had gained a reputation of being an ideal place of tourism and leisure. The hotel became the meeting point for ool executives, airline tycoons, and renowned bankers. 
Celebrities from around the world would visit the hotel.
properties.data-Q-Bibliography:
Strategically located at the tip of the bay of Saint-Georges in Beirut, the H�tel Saint-Georges is an icon of modern architecture in Lebanon, designed by�the French firm of Poirrier, Lotte and Bordes with Lebanese engineer-architect Antoine Tabet as architect on site.[1]
The building clearly bears the influence of Auguste Perret with its rational organization of space and exposed concrete.
It has a modular plan based on a triple grid: 7 x 7 meters, 7 x 3.5 meters and 3.5 x 3.5 meters, skillfully adapted to the functional needs. The plan of the hotel was organized around an open-air courtyard under which is found the kitchen, located there to avoid the harsh sun, while serving both the restaurant and the terraces outside.[2]�The horizontal dominance of the hotel, resulting from the balconies surrounding its massive block and the daring use of exposed concrete, give the design its distinctive character. The guardrail is made of ornamental hollowed concrete blocks with wide openings in order to allow for maximum ventilation and view. The upper parts of the doors and windows are treated, also for ventilation purposes, with hollow blocks of a tighter grid. The massive water tank was built from the start at roof level, taking into consideration the extension of the third and fourth floors that were added at a later stage; it also carried the hotel sign, executed in relief with concrete blocks.
(George Arbid)
�

[1]Later, in 1946-47, Tabet was in charge of adding to the building the third and fourth floors, and enlarging the restaurant.
[2]Poirrier went on to design the H�tel Saada in Agadir, Morocco in 1951-53, a copy of the H�tel Saint-Georges, with Bordes, Abran & Bassi�res. 


- Techniques et Architecture, September 1952, p. 53.
- l'Architecture Fran�aise juillet aout 1946

properties.data-B-Architect: J. Aractingi,J. Nassar,P. Neema & J. N. Conan(CETA)
properties.data-D-SpeChar: The piazza,it is raised form on prestressed concrete columns allowing for a flexible floor plan and unobstructed view of the nearby Mediterranean from the street,green public spaces,prefabricated sun shaders that start in a playful geometric arrangement,floaghting garden terrace, claustra, glazed staircase,view on the gf open to the sea
properties.data-P-SpcScMn:
The building represents a period when the Lebanese authorities were equiping the country with needed infrastructure.
Another social/urban meaning is the open sunken piazza as public space.
properties.data-Q-Bibliography:
The team won the competition in 1965*, construction started in 1967 and ended in 1972.

By locating the main public area under the building, open to a piazza, not only did the team offer the neighborhood an interesting urban space, but a view to the sea as well. That was achieved with a remarkable structure consisting of 4 porticos in prestressed concrete, 14-meter span, proposed by Joseph Nassar, the team engineer. Given the large spans, a free partitioning of the floors was possible. On the southern sunny side, the building carries a large and deep claustra veil, contributing to its lightness. 
In the execution phase, structural engineer No�l Abouhamad was called in for the calculation of the precast slabs, a field he had experimented in since the late 1950s.

*Results announced on 12 April 1965.
Among the competitors were architects Pierre El Khoury and Kazim Kenan.
Renowned Italian architect Gio Ponti was in the jury.
According to Jean-No�l Conan and Pierre Neema, Henri Edd� tried to stop the building because of the presence of Conan (a foreigner) in the team.

"Practicing Modernism in Beirut, Architecture in Lebanon,1946-1970" by Dr George J. Arbid,ACA-CETAcollection

properties.data-D-SpeChar: T shaped glass box,maximum transparency,arched colums that supported by a flat roof,each supporting point was made of four square steel columns that spread diagonally to meet their counterparts,the columns formed a skeleton of a groined vault
properties.data-P-SpcScMn: 7 major crafts exhibiltions and other venues such as architecture diplomas exhibitions
properties.data-Q-Bibliography:
La Maison de l�Artisan was a project destined to exhibit craft products on a beautiful site by the sea. The building was a T-shaped glass box that ensured maximum transparency on all sides. In order to give the building a �character of Lebanese inspiration,� arched columns supported the flat roof. Each supporting point was made of four square steel columns that spread diagonally to meet their counterparts, thus, virtually forming the skeleton of a groined vault. They were originally planned in concrete, but were executed in steel, a more feasible solution (The contractor, engineer Panay Akl convinced them that steel would be more appropriate. A blacksmith from Tripoli executed the remarkably well-done steelwork, and the low parts of the steel columns were filled with concrete).
 As an answer to a delicate program with a need for attention to representation, the commissioner (the CEGP), saw in this project �a clever evocation of tradition.� The structural idea for this project came from a previous project designed in 1956-57 by J. N. Conan: A technical school for handicapped children in Garches, near Paris. With a slight suggestion of the familiar arch in an otherwise �Miesian� box, the team resolved the paradox of compliance with the wishes of the CEGP to have a �Lebanese� building, and at the same time allow for maximum transparency, lightness and polyvalence of exhibition space, all modernist attributes. The building was disfigured in 1999 by a shameless rehabilitation that transformed it into a d�cor recalling 1001 nights in which the glass walls were blocked by concrete, with an adobe finish, and the virtual vaults determined by the skeletons were filled with �real/fake� vaults of plaster.

Al-Mouhandess 6 January 1966,"Practicing Modernism in Beirut, Architecture in Lebanon,1946-1970" by Dr George J. Arbid

properties.data-D-SpeChar: Had a showroom on the 3rd floor.Every facade is treated differently,curtain wall on the northern side,vertical sunscreen on the easter side,horizontal sunscreen on the southern.A precast concrete wall that separate the northern and the eastern elevation and ties the building to the ground.The gf was made to hold 5 tons/m2,very high weight.There is a rolling bridge of the Gf for trucks to enter.The building has schindler's first electric prototype elevator.In the interior,the offices are equipped with movable panels. Built in closets in the wall of the offices on the 2nd floor. Openings on top of the wall that allows light to pass from the offices to the corridor. Building core that acts as services. Clustra panels on the west facade and a huge panel on the south facade.
properties.data-P-SpecHsEv: In 1978 Syrians broke into Pierre michaca building and stayed in it for a year. They also did alot of destruction.
properties.data-P-SpcScMn: Events used to happen when Pierre michaca gets a new machine.
properties.data-Q-Bibliography:
The Michaca Building, an office building with a showroom on the ground floor, is probably the most rational of Karam�s buildings, and a watered down version of his formal experiments. The northern side is a curtain wall benefiting from a maximum of light, while the eastern side is veiled with vertical sunscreens, and the southern side protected with horizontal sunscreens. A wall made of textured precast concrete panels, including pebbles, separates the northern and eastern elevations and ties the building to the ground.

Paper by Tania Arwachan for George arbid's class "Beirut Modern" at AUB fall 2003,ACA-JPKaramcollection
properties.data-R-Notes: In the main office of michaca there is big sliding wood door,they added gypsum board ceiling on the corridor were all electric cables are,they added parquet to thw offices,the west facade was curtain wall but they closed it with concrete blocks to reach a window for security reasons,the second and the third floor are now rented by companies such as play med,dunkin,simsom and ashkar structural consultants who rented some of the offices on the 2nd floor. Aluminum composite panels on the ground floor level is added and a stair is added so it became a showroom for a cars company ,also covering half of the pebbled wall. Pierre michaca and JP karam were good friends thats why he chose him as an architect for his building.

properties.data-A-BlckNo: Block A(rectangular block), Block B(square block),block C (the 2 ground floors)
properties.data-D-SpeChar: 30 and 60 degree grid, stolls arranged in jagged pattern to insure the fluid space,atruims that are largely open to public space and connected  by vertical connections,Block B has a central core in which the vertical circulation and floor services are grouped,long windows that shows that vertical load bearing structure is setback from facade,double sheets of glass louvers,a high-tech center,colums clad with black sheets to give a floating appearance,Block A and Block B are arranged in compositional settings
properties.data-G-OtGFUsg: 2 Gfs that function as Commercial, the lower gf had a cinema room and restaurant,gas station and small parking.cinema was transformed into a Nightclub in 2001
properties.data-H-OtStrShp: Block A spiral,Block B two flights
properties.data-Q-Bibliography:
The Starco, an office building and commercial center, sits between two streets at different levels, thus benefiting from two shopping floors. Due to the presence of a road that connects the two streets, the upper shopping level is connected with a pedestrian bridge. Stairs and escalators allow for comfortable and uninterrupted strolling. The two levels of shopping are topped with two office towers, the higher one being square in plan, the lower one rectangular, arranged in a compositional setting. The center was undoubtedly high-tech by the time�s standards, fully air-conditioned, with state of the art electrical and mechanical systems. The columns, clad with black sheets of glass, give a floating appearance to the white masses of the two office buildings. The uninterrupted horizontal bands of windows are made of double sheets of glass, with internal micro louvers for screening purposes, a device quite new at the time of construction. (used by Addor et Julliard in their office building for Conrad Zschokke in Geneva one year earlier).
The movie theater was transformed into a night club in 2001.
Architect in charge, Willy Lups, collaborators: Walter Bayerl and Pierre Meier. Structural engineer Conrad Zschokke of Geneva, with Lebanese associate Fayez Ahdab. Lebanese superintendants: Hagop Atechian, Mohamed Ali Reda and Joseph Bechir.

Bolliger et Lelouch/Habib Sayah,Orient Le Jour 23/5/97,Architecture design march 1963,BLF,"Construire A Distance:Les realisations de L'agence immobiliere genevoise addor et julliard a beyrouth dans les annees 1950-1960" by Habib Sayah,"Practicing Modernism in Beirut, Architecture in Lebanon,1946-1970" by Dr George J. Arbid
properties.data-R-Notes: Al awar was responsible for the concrete works, for the upper floors area: Block A: 13887, Block B: 7608. Also contacted dr Habib Sayyah

properties.data-A-BldgName: National Museum of Antiquities in Beirut
properties.data-D-SpeChar: Was designed in a French inspired Egyptian Revival architecture
properties.data-P-SpecHsEv:
In 1919, a little gathering of antiquated ancient rarities gathered by Raymond Weill, a French official positioned in Lebanon, was shown at a temporary exhibition hall in the Kaiserswerth Deaconesses' structure in Georges Picot Road, Beirut.

In the interim, a trailblazer of the Archeological and Expressive arts Administration started to collect things from the area round Beirut.

In 1923, the "Companions of the Gallery Advisory group", headed by Bechara El Khoury, then, at that point, Top state leader and pastor of training and expressive arts, was made to raise assets to construct a public historical center.

The board of trustees acknowledged the plans introduced by engineers Antoine Nahas and Pierre Leprince-Ringuet. Development started in 1930 on a plot of land gave by the region close to the Beirut Hippodrome, and was finished in 1937.

In 1975, with the flare-up of the Lebanese conflict, Beirut was parted into two restricting regions. The public gallery and the directorate general of artifacts were on the outline line known as "Exhibition hall rear entryway" what isolated the fighting local armies and armed forces. Conditions in the quick area of the exhibition hall quickly declined, as the historical center suffered shelling and bombarding, and was transformed into a military quarters for soldiers.
The main intends to reestablish the public exhibition hall came in 1992 from Michel Edde, then, at that point, Clergyman of Culture and Advanced education. The proposition to destroy the substantial dividers and cases which safeguarded the irreplaceable assets was turned somewhere near the overall overseer of artifacts, Camille Asmar, since the historical center actually had no entryways or windows to forestall further plundering. Ghassan Tueni gave the assets for the gallery's monstrous new fundamental entryway. When the entryways and windows were placed in, the choice was made to pull down the substantial divider that safeguarded the entry to the storm cellar. Reclamation work began in 1995 and zeroed in on the actual structure, and the reviewing and rebuilding of the assortment. The exhibition hall was authoritatively introduced on November 25, 1997 by then president Elias Hrawi yet just pieces of the ground floor and cellar were made open since the rest of the structure was as yet under fix and significant changes were expected to meet the necessities of present day museology guidelines.
properties.data-P-SpcScMn: Museums are primarily educational institutions; what makes them public institutions for the presevation of culture is their educational work. Museums represent a major public social investment by most modern societies.
properties.data-Q-Bibliography1: - Arab Center for Architecture - Antoine Nahas and Pierre Leprince Ringuet collection
properties.data-Q-Bibliography:
When confronted to give a style to the National Museum of Antiquities that was to house mainly Phoenician archeological findings, nobody knew what Phoenician Architecture looked like. As a result of a competition launched in 1927-28, the Museum was designed in the Pharaonic style by Leprince-Ringuet a French architect and Antoine Nahas (1903-1966), an Egyptian born architect who was his student in Paris.
Their design bears a striking resemblance to the unbuilt project for a museum in Cairo, Egypt, designed in 1926 by Welles Bosworth (the architect of the main building at MIT in 1913).
Construction began in 1930. The museum was opened to the public in 1938, but inaugurated only in 1942.
The museum was renovated in 1997 by French interior designer Jean-Michel Wilmotte.
*The jury met on February 28, 1928 at the National Library, under the Presidency of Bechara El Khoury, then Prime Minister and Minister of Education and Fine Arts. The examining commission had nominated three projects:
1- "Lion" by Pierre Leprince-Ringuet & Antoine Nahas
2- "Antar" by Alexandre Boevivald
3- "Alma" by Jean Germain and Octave Hanemoglou
Projects 2 and 3 were awarded supplementary prizes.

properties.data-A-Owner: Mr sinno,the president of the Makassed Islamic Association
properties.data-D-SpeChar: The ground floor is liberated and becomes a covered playground,homogeneous supply of light on one side and irregular composition of openings on the other,double orientation of light
properties.data-P-SpcScMn: Ceremonies and graduations
properties.data-Q-Bibliography:
The Al Thani Makassed School is an example of rationalist architecture in Beirut, signed by Amine Bizri.*
The building rests on pilotis. The ground floor is thus liberated and becomes a covered playground. The east and west elevations are treated differently due to the plan that offers the classrooms on one side and a corridor leading to them on the other, hence a repetitive and homogeneous supply of light on one side and an irregular composition of openings on the other. With high openings found on top of the walls separating the corridor from the classrooms, the latter benefit from a double orientation of light, thus a reduction of the glare.
*After a degree in engineering from ESIB in 1947, Amin Bizri studied architecture the Ecole des Beaux-Arts de Paris, following the Perret atelier. He graduated in 1950 and briefly trained at Perret's office. In 1953, Bizri earned a degree in planning from the Universit� de Paris.
Bizri collaborated with many architects, namely Schayer-Adib on the Ghandour factory in Choueifat, and Pierre Neema on the Chamber of Commerce and Industry in Sanayeh. In 1965, he was elected President of the Order of Engineers and Architects at the age of 40.
Additionally, Amine Bizri held many positions in the administration.

"Practicing Modernism in Beirut, Architecture in Lebanon,1946-1970" by Dr George J. Arbid

properties.data-D-SpeChar: Building looks like a spaceship,sharp pointed roof,serenity from the inside vs aggressive urban gesture from the outside,central core that serves for circulation,levels,light by openings that led the light penetrate through reflection
properties.data-J-OtFlFns: White scratch resistant Formica panels on plywood boards
properties.data-Q-Bibliography:
In the 1970s, Khalil Khoury's work had shifted towards a quest for strong sculptural presence as evidenced by his building for Michel Khodr of 1972 in Hamra. 
The Interdesign furniture showroom is a "brutalist" building that gives the impression of a vertical spaceship with an odd sharply pointed roof. What seems to be a blunt, unsophisticated and aggressive urban gesture, is tempered by excessive serenity inside. While the outside is treated in fair-faced concrete, the exhibition is a play on three levels surrounding the central core that serves for circulation, with voids between the three platforms at full height. The spatial device is very efficient, offering vistas on the exhibited furniture at various levels, the most interesting one being the possibility to appreciate comfortably the profile of seats and tables.
Natural light is controlled by fully exposing one of the two walls facing north with a curtain-wall, while the south and east are treated with beveled walls allowing for indirect light to filter in.
Construction had started in 1975 and due to the war, it was interrupted many times, to be finally completed by 1997.
It should be noted that however spatially interesting they are, the voids were devised by the architect to by-pass the building code, as he convinced the authorities that they should not be counted in the permitted building area (Khalil Khoury, interview by author).
properties.data-R-Notes: The building was finished after the war in 1997, the areas are on the plans

properties.data-D-SpeChar: Vertical art deco style,inspired by the skyscrapers he saw in New York,first concrete structure in Lebanon and arguably in Middle East,Highest structure in Lebanon,a central shaft with set of stairs and elevator connected to Charles corm personal offices,Modern furniture obtained from Mies van der Rohe,followed the concept of domino house for structure,free walls,rooftop was constructed in wood and changed to concrete in renovation

properties.data-Q-Bibliography: Built in the late 20s by Charles Corm to house the Ford agency at first and later became Corm�s house with a remarkable library space on the upper floor. Its vertical Art deco style must have been quite impressive at the time. Corm who was not an architect, was in fact inspired by his visit to New York.

properties.data-D-SpeChar: Composition of straight and curved lines,modernized cornices,play of masses and voids created by terraces,layout that ensures cross ventilation,staircase is around a void  and its lit from above,crowned with a distinctive top.
properties.data-Q-Bibliography:
Designed by Najib Shoucair, the Gebrane Metni Building is typical of the exuberant yet properly balanced apartment buildings of the late 1940s.* It displays a tempered composition of straight and curved lines, enriched by simple modernized cornices and a play of masses and voids created by terraces, reinforced by the uniformity of material (plaster finish and paint on cyclopean wall). With its south elevation facing the street, the building creates what Le Corbusier called the "jeu savant et magnifique des volumes assembl�s sous la lumi�re."
The lower ground floor and ground floor were built in 1949. Four  floors were added in 1956 and one floor in 1973.
The general layout ensures cross ventilation. Bedrooms have two openings for ventilation as well. The staircase is around a void and it is lit from above, crowned with a distinctive top.
* Najib Shoucair (1906-1971) was a "Mouhandess Moumaress," engineer by practice. He was at some point in his career the Director of Roads at the Ministry of Public works in Beirut, and later in Zahl�.

ACA-Najib Scoucair collection

properties.data-D-SpeChar:
Theatre that follow italian style theatre, with a proscenium, an orchestra and 2 balconies.
A dome that covers the space of the audience has apparent concrete ribs  that is topped by electrically operated steel dome.
properties.data-P-SpecHsEv:
Initially known as �Le Grand Theatre des Milleset une Nuit�, which is French for: �The One thousand and One nights Theater� offered a diverse set of shows in different languages, ballets, comedies, local theaters� 
In 1960 it was transformed into a movie theater, a cinema.
In 1975 During the war the Grand Theater with its stable excessive structure stood tall.
In 1990 When the war was over Solidere took custody of the building.
properties.data-P-SpcScMn: Entertainment and engage the community in different dialogues
properties.data-Q-Bibliography1: - Arab Center for Architecture - Youssef Aftimus collection
properties.data-Q-Bibliography:
The Grand Th��tre was built by Jacques Tabet. A cultured man, Tabet contributed to periodicals of the 1920s and 1930s like Ph�nicia and La Revue Ph�nicienne. He was a poet and was fond of theatre.
Although the building is commonly attributed to Youssef Aftimus, original plans signed by Aftimus were not discovered. On the other hand, copies of original drawings hold the signatures of Germain and Hanemoglou. In the absence of undisputable evidence accrediting the design to Aftimus, we are left with speculations. In any case, Aftimus must have had a role in the building.
Whether designed by Aftimus, by Hanemoglou and Germain, or by someone else, the Grand Th��tre is definitely an eclectic building by the mere fact that it had to temper between an orientalist fa�ade and a contemporary program in its core, namely the theatre. For such a program, the architect had to recourse to an appropriate material like reinforced concrete, yet operate a dialogue with the neighboring buildings all built in stone.
The program of the building comprised several functions distributed among a basement, four stories from ground level, and a roof floor. At street level, fourteen shops are found in total, ten giving on Rue de Syrie and four on Rue Emir B�chir. They were mostly bookshops and used the basements for storage.
The theatre follows the Italian style theatre, with a proscenium, an orchestra and 2 balconies. The horse-shoe shape has a round space for the audience, like old theatres in London. Although the Grand Th��tre is often compared to the Op�ra Garnier in Paris, mostly for its flat-domed ceiling, its dome does not show from the outside, hidden as it is by the apartments that give onto the streets. From inside, the dome that covers the space of the audience has apparent concrete ribs and is topped by a small electrically operated steel dome sliding on rails and providing excellent ventilation. The start of the show was announced by the gentle sliding of the dome, the disappearance of the sky, and the falling in darkness. The Grand Th��tre offered a perfect sight as the spectators experienced a plunging view on the wide stage. It was praised by the performers who experienced its good acoustics, even before the presence of microphones.

properties.data-D-SpeChar: Geometric and decorative elements, a central hall with three openings that leads to a liwan, distinctive internal heritage elements, three openings,arches,columns, and decorated capitals, and heritage tiles on the floors and exteriors on its heritage facades of dotted corners, openings and decorative elements, arches and lintels. The ornate arches and double arches with their wrought iron within an ornate frame, ornate cornices, balconies connected with western verandas, cement arches and ornate sapphires, distinguished by its style and the richness of its plastic and decorative elements, a garden on the south and west sides, including a cement pergola.
properties.data-P-SpecHsEv: It was the residence of Sheikh Muhammad al-Jisr, one of the most prominent politicians in the State of Greater Lebanon, around which the majority of political forces, Christian and Islamic, gathered in the battle for the presidency of the republic in 1932. His son Muhammad inhabited it after him the bridge.
properties.data-P-SpcScMn: The building also has a planning value through its location supervising Mar Elias and Dinnawi streets, which still contains a few heritage buildings.
properties.data-Q-Bibliography:
The property is located at the intersection of Mar Elias and Dinnawi Streets.The existing building dates back to the first part of the twentieth century and belongs to the style of Mandate engineering in terms of its formation, materials, and geometric and decorative elements. The building still retains its formation (a central hall with three openings that leads to a liwan with three openings surrounding the rooms of the house) and its distinctive internal heritage elements, including three openings, arches, columns, and decorated capitals, and heritage tiles on the floors and exteriors on its heritage facades of dotted corners, openings and decorative elements, arches and lintels. The ornate arches and double arches with their wrought iron within an ornate frame, ornate cornices, balconies connected with western verandas, cement arches and ornate sapphires.
This building is distinguished by its style and the richness of its plastic and decorative elements, which makes it a necessity to preserve it not only because of its distinctive heritage value, but because it is unique in its kind and the last witness to this style in the region.
The building consists of a basement floor, a ground floor and three upper floors, connected by a north-east staircase, surrounded by a garden on the south and west sides, including a cement pergola on the south-west side. The property also contains three stores on its southern facade, which overlooks Al-Dennawi Street.

properties.data-D-SpeChar: Porthole windows, capital columns, arches, iron and wood work, a public garden next to it.
properties.data-P-SpecHsEv:
The building of the Wilayah Houd School, transformed by the Ottoman Sultan, Abdul Hamid II (1842-1918), from a military school for officers, into a free school for the education of children and young people from the sons and residents of Beirut. In 1888,

The construction of the Ottoman Rashidiya Military School began, at the instruction of Sultan Abdul Hamid II. year 1877. Three years later, the school began training officers from Lebanon, Syria and Palestine, including the Lebanese Noureddine Al-Rifai (1899-1980), who headed a military government at the beginning of the civil war (1975).

The name of the school goes back to the presence of a fresh water spring that irrigated Beirut, so the Ottoman administrator at the time ordered the construction of a large basin, for the people of the area to benefit from. Its name became (Bad al-Wilayah).

Between 1888 and 1915 the huge building, with 40 spacious rooms on three high-ceilinged floors, with a very long foyer on each floor, was restricted to the graduation of officers.

In 1918, Abd al-Hamid II gave the building to a school, and its restoration began (after being bombed during the First World War between 1914-1918).
At the beginning of the twentieth century, most of the Ottoman courts in Beirut were transformed into schools, including the Girls' College (Al-Makassed).

In 2001, the Ministry of Education named the school �Mofti Martyr Hassan Khaled High School� in his memory.
properties.data-P-SpcScMn: Being a school, lots of graduates, secondary school, next to a public garden, point of attraction.

properties.data-A-Owner: First owner Moarbes family, second owner Saaddine El Wazzan
properties.data-D-SpeChar: arcades that run along two of its facades, garden with water basin, central hall plan, interior baroque staircase, pilasters, corbels and consoles, painted stucco ceiling, interior water basin, carved and painted wood beams,  it was the first residence in Lebanon to feature amenities such as modern bathrooms, running water and electricity
properties.data-P-SpecHsEv:
The building was the property of the Mezher family who were important landowners in the neighborhood.
It then served as the premises of the United States Consulate-General in Syria between 1914 and 1936, with a short intermezzo as Dutch consulate during the World War I.
After 1936 it became the family residence of Marie Mezher often known as Marie Bahar, after her father's nickname and her husband, the medical doctor Joseph Hunieni. Between 1968 and her death in 1970, Marie Mezher-Henein� ran a restaurant, Le Petit Palais, on the first floor.
After Mezher-Henein�'s death, the floor remained abandoned until it was squatted by displaced families in 1977. The preservation and restoration of this outstanding mansion- damaged by war and neglected- is urgently damaged by war is urgently recommended.
properties.data-P-SpcScMn: series of events, in and around the palace, in order to allow the public to discover the palace's exceptional beauty and value.
properties.data-Q-Bibliography:
The two-story building appears conventional and austere from the outside, with the exception of its long-arched gallery overlooking Rue Abdel Kader. 
The layout includes a large entrance hall with a pair of curved flights of stairs embracing a fountain and leading up to a vestibule in the center of the house; from here, doors open onto the drawing and sitting rooms (grand salon and petit salon), a dining room, a corridor leading to the kitchen, and some additional rooms.
This atypical spatial organization is striking evidence of the bourgeois European lifestyle. He is also in charge of the beautiful interior design, most notably the Alhambra-inspired grand salon with its marble fountain, multifoil arches, murqarnas friezes, and lavish stucco ceilings inlaid with mirrors. It is a 'imagined Orient' transformed into stone and plaster, and it is one of the earliest examples of a Mauresque interior in Beirut.

properties.data-B-Architect: The Danish company Kampax, the Swedish agri-consult malm�
properties.data-B-Contractor: Rodolphe Elias (Cessionnaire Ramez Kfoury), Strojexport (with Czech firm Pr_mstav)
properties.data-D-SpeChar: Gliding framework
properties.data-P-SpecHsEv:
September 16, 1968: The construction of the grain silos at the port of Beirut was launched during the term of President Charles El-Helou. 
1970: the building was completed and put into operation with 42 cylindrical silos and a capacity of 2,500 tons of grain per cylinder.
War 1975-1990: The silos were well-preserved, even after witnessing two wars and withstanding multiple missile attacks.
1997: the structure underwent restoration and expansion works: 6 cylinders of the same storage capacity were added.
2000- 2002: Another restoration campaign was carried out to address the concrete carbonation. During this campaign, the internal walls of the outer rows of the silos were increased by 12 cm. 
August 4th 2020: A massive explosion struck the port of Beirut. The grain silos, standing at 85 meters from the blast epicenter, took the brunt of the impact. The east-facing concrete cylinders collapsed at the spot, yet west-facing ones remain partially standing.
March 18th 2022: 18 months after the explosion, the Minister of Culture, Mohammad Mortada, issued a decree No. 49/2022 to include the grain silos building in the general inventory of heritage buildings.
April 14th 2022 the Lebanese Cabinet issued a decree to demolish the silos and to erect a new monument to commemorate the victims.
properties.data-P-SpcScMn: A landmark for beirutis before the explosion, and a silo for their grains. After the august 4 explosion, the image of the crumbling grain silos was shared around the globe as a symbol of the tragedy that hit Beirut on that day. The site of the silos became an assembly point for the families of the victims and the Lebanese demanding justice following the August 4th blast. People expressed their grief and anger and commemorated the victims on the fence of the site. Most of the media coverage and statements related to the Beirut's explosion took place in front of the grain silos.
properties.data-Q-Bibliography1:
"Rehabilitation of Silos Beirut Port", Khatib & Alami, Beirut
"Beirut Grain Silos", 
ACA Archives- Grain silos in Beirut Port
properties.data-Q-Bibliography:
Beirut's grain silos were the biggest silos in the middle east (1968) . The original capacity of the silos consisted of 42 cylindrical silos of a diameter of 8.5 m with a capacity of 2,500 tons of grain per cylinder. After restoration work took place in 1997, 6 cylinders were added but the study was not accurate and the addition collapsed. 
It has a brutalist architecture style and monolithic shape.
The basic materials for the production of concrete were of local origin. As the only rock in the country, Portland cement of local production was of excellent quality. A specific prescribed type of cement, resistant to seawater's effects, was supplied to produce concrete for the piles and the foundations.
Cost at the time: 15,5 million Lebanese Pounds
Fascinating job: 105,000 tons; 30,700 cubic meters of concrete poured in formworks gliding on rails; non-stop in 10-12 days and nights at a rate of 3.6 meters every 24 hours; height: 63 meters.
